commentBody:
Today I achieved a 200-day streak! This puzzle felt like it had a nice theme, but it seems a little confusing out of context. I erased several of my answers crossing theme entries because they didn't make sense before I found out what the theme was. Nice puzzle just was slightly difficult to take from a blank grid. 

Going for 365 days next!

I came in through the bathroom window. 
Hope the front door opens soon.

(Did a URL go Down instead of Up?)
It's been a while since I was this much on the constructor's wavelength, puzzle practically filled itself!
Less than half my average Thursday time.  The link to this discussion is broken on the iOS app (at least for me).  I had to search for it…
The Cinephile channel is TCM, not TMC

1. With great power comes great responsibility the proper answer is Uncle Ben TO Spiderman!
Had to get that off my chest!! 
However being a circus fan loved Big Top. Wanted to put Barry Bond not Babe Ruth but land of talking animals and magic clued one of my favourite fantasy book series Narnia.

I'm really missing rebus puzzles, answers that are out side the grid, or inside the black squares, or some kind of twist that the last few Thursday puzzles have been lacking. No dis to the constructor,  it was a nice puzzle, some fun clues, but it's time for a real Thursday.  

Pretty please?

Not me screaming EUREKA when I figured out the revealer. 

Oh that was a treat.  Do come back. Southwest corner stumped me, I guess I need more time at the BIGTOP.

I was confused initially when ROCKCLIMBER didn't work but I figured the answer would reveal itself eventually. Sure enough, after several crosses the answer became obvious, and then I rapidly filled in the rest of the themers. 

I had to let go of TCM for Turner Classic Movies and to with TMC for The Movie Channel, even though cinephiles watch the former moreso than the latter. However, that was the only way the SPIDERMAN was going to scale that wall.

Fun puzzle!

I didn't like this much.  Way, way too easy for a Thursday.  The gimmick was immediately obvious, and the only mystery was what the revealer would turn out to be... And then, it wasn't good?  It would have made a bit more sense if it said scale "up" but I suppose the constructor avoided that because he or she had already written "start-up".

That was a bad decision.  Ah well.  Maybe next Tuesday will be rewarding/ challenging.  These are too often mixed bags.  :(
I had DISH instead of DIRT which gave me HBO instead of TMC.
Okay sorry, but it was Uncle Ben, not Spider-Man
I'll die on the hill that Sunset Boulevard can't be officially classified as a film noir... but I suppose I get how "satirical Gothic melodrama" probably wouldn't fit on any day but a Sunday

I really had to grind this one out.  

Nothing seemed to come easily.  I wrestled with several wrong answers that I was sure of:  AnalyZE instead of AGONIZE, Rush instead of RACE, left instead of MALE, BAnKING instead of BACKING.  Of course all this with rockcLimbeR instead of REBMILCKCOR, which just obliterated everything.

I was pretty well beaten until I finally decided saw that I almost had WINDOW backwards.  With that click, it all came into focus.

But it was nip and tuck up to that point.

Once I stopped thinking musical scales the balloon went up.

I blame that DO at the start of the 26d reveal.  Oh deer.
I'm too old for yet another playground retort.
I had ROpeCLIMBER for much of the puzzle, and the crossing words for those two letters were no help at all, so the end game took me way too long.
Also I must say: the less time I have to spend thinking about investors and the "growth at all cost" mindset that ruins most businesses, the better.

So for those who say that I never criticize puzzles, this one didn’t rise to the occasion for me. First, an inconsistent theme—3 people and an object? Why  word it as a reply to the revealer then, since a grapevine can’t talk? In any case what is “it”? The first three aren’t “its”. Then I thought maybe it’s the profession that scales, punnily, but Spider-Man isn’t a profession and a grapevine certainly isn’t. I’ll grant a certain leeway to a tentative revealer if the theme is really imaginative or creative, but an obviously backwards theme doesn’t fit that bill.
Second, the fill—about average difficulty for me—was only meh. An awful lot of glue I think and nothing really very interesting on accessory entries. Babe Ruth? Noah’s Ark clued in a cute but trite way? Yawn. My only bright spot was GOMEZ Addams who for me will always be the incomparable John Astin (no offense Raul Julia and Nathan Lane), who also gets extra points for adopting and raising Sean Astin (Samwise). Otherwise, sorry, this one just didn’t get off the ground.
I’m neither a beginner nor an expert solver, and I enjoyed this puzzle.  Lots of clever clues, I thought.

Took a while for the SCALEs to fall from my eyes and understand the trick. This would have made a very nice Wednesday puzzle. But the inclusion of GRAPEVINE made me think of the opening to a great 1980s movie. Yeah, I'm old. https://youtu.be/az-VjJLwn2I?si=e-kqr2XrN545ZhJN
For me, the link from the phone app must have a typo.  Got here by searching… but earlier my laptop found these comments no problem.

Not for me. 

First of all, who the h___ says "Tap an ALE"?
Or "EDGE toward"?

Plus, I (apparently unlike Deb, and most prior commenters) have never been in any investor's meetings, and have never heard the phrase "Does it scale".  On top of that, I think it's a very poor revealer, since in the phrase, "scale" refers to size, not climbing.

BTW - Merriam-Webster lists 4 nouns with 30 definitions, and 3 verbs with 17 definitions under the entry "scale".  One - and only one - of those 47 definitions uses the word "up".

"Want to go rock climbing with me?"
"Nah, you're boulder than I am."

(These puns get a belayed reaction.)

This one took me way longer than it might have if I weren't so tired tonight. I kept erasing correct answers and sticking with incorrect ones (circus before BIG TOP, TrAm before TBAR, keg before ALE, BAnKING before BACKING, iseEit before EUREKA, DIsh before DIRT). The trick to the theme answers was just not coming to me, so I figured my crosses had to be wrong. What answers could possibly end in COR, NIW, or PARG? 

It was PARG that did it for me because I felt very confident in those crosses and finally thought to read up instead of down. Oh!!! I'd actually thought of two correct theme answers, rockclimber and windowwasher. Once I realized how to enter them, the rest of the puzzle was easy.

It's so weird when your brain is too exhausted to function well, but you don't feel sleepy, so you don't realize you're tired and assume it's that the puzzle is extra hard. 

Okay. Just took my gummy. Night night!

MATE in three?

No comprendo.

N
U
F
Link to tips not working.

This was a weird experience for me.

The puzzle was generally easy and I figured out the trick on its first, very obvious entry - having done the across pass first, I had enough crosses there to spot ROCK CLIMBER immediately. Being a (gym) climber myself helped, I guess. It was a bit of a letdown, to be honest. Granted, it took me a while to figure out the other entries, but realizing the gist of the trick I've been waiting for for a week on its first clue was an anticlimax.

Still, the fill confused me in places, but not for fun reasons. I have no idea what a BIG TOP is or who the Flying Wallendas are, for example. In the end I needed several lookups to deal with the grid.

Also, are we asking about friggin *corn syrup brands* now? Seriously... I'm glad I got it from crosses, but c'mon. Surely that's going too far with trivia? I haven't been that annoyed by a crossword entry in ages.

On a positive note, the neighbors are in love with our puppy. Grown men and women are awwing over him on out walks 😍. Next week we're starting doggie kindergarten. I can't wait! Watching the dog learn new stuff is so awesome 🤩

Pretty clever, those SCALEs. Finally figured out what was going on with ROCKCLIMBER. I thought NOTATE as clued was loosely tied in with the theme if I thought about musical scales. Anyway, I also had DIsh and then aMC before DIRT and cIrcus before BIGTOP. Like Vaer, I also thought of The Big Chill when I saw GRAPEVINE. That soundtrack evokes great memories for me. It also makes me think of this commercial… https://youtu.be/vcDGbaCsatQ?si=VT9I5C4fNX8z1jCV Thanks, Colin!

It would've been fun if it was at all hinted at that the special answers were in reverse. But it wasn't. Just because there was the word scale in one hint does not make it so.
Also I'd say Uncle Ben was the one who popularized the saying but sure, Spiderman works too
Because I knew or had heard of all the answers and got the theme early on, I was able to complete this puzzle in 48% less time than average.  Or perhaps I just rose to the occasion.
same here
A lot of this appeared nonsense on the first go-round. Still no idea what "tap an ale" might mean. Thanks for the explainer for the maddening parts!
But it’s SANtiago!
Bad URL. Directs to “Page not found.”
athlete tackling El Capitan?  Rock Climber fit perfectly and it was all downhill from there.  Too tough for me.

I started solving the puzzle when I went to bed. But after getting ROCK CLIMBER and grasping the trick I found it almost impossible to keep my eyes open (I hadn’t slept much Tuesday night). 

Coming back to it during tonight’s bout of insomnia, I finished it up without much trouble. I’ve not heard the revealer phrase before, but I can imagine someone saying it.

I’m not fond of grids in which answers appear to be gibberish. 

The too-easy clueing meant that the only challenge for me was staying awake. 

Nice try, Mr. Ernst, but overall disappointing.

Sunset Boulevard is one of my favorite movies. I wouldn’t call it NOIR, though it certainly has some elements of a classic film noir. This recent WaPo article about the movie is worth reading. https://wapo.st/4630D2J

I thought this was great.

Paused a bit to remind myself that it's Thursday, then did my usual passes, skipping over the long ones until I had something more to hold onto, and that's when I realized something strange, not sure what, was going on. How could I be so off base with so many long answers?

I think VINE was first, and then the rest fell pretty quickly. My only real holdup was DIsh.ANKAsA, hMC.

Speaking of KARO syrup, we have a couple of jars in the pantry, probably for a recipe we wound up not making, but is there even another brand out there?

I enjoyed 17A, but my favorite BABERUTH quote was his reply when a reporter asked him what he thought about getting paid more than the President. "Hell, I had a better year than he did".

Thanks!

Once in a while, when I think I’ve seen every trick in the book, a new one comes along. This was not that day. Sometimes I miss being that newbie who sees repeated tricks for the first time, and marvels at them. Alas, the totally fresh ideas are few and far between. There have been 47 puzzles in the history of he NYT that required backwards answers, plus another half dozen or so that had a backwards trick within certain answers. One puzzle required ALL the downs to be entered as “ups.” It was pre-Shortz, so you can’t solve it via the NYT archive, but you can if you’re a member at Xword info.com. For Xword info members, here’s the unsolved grid: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Solve?psdate=5/20/1990 For everyone else, here’s the completed grid for that puzzle: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=5/20/1990

A contestant came onto that budding entrepreneur show with a fish processing invention, and the very first question was . . 

. . . Yes, but DOESITSCALE?!

My Partner and I live on the seventeenth floor of a high-rise co-op--really nineteenth, counting the lobby and mezzanine. (Sorry to brag, but the view is stunning.) The last couple weeks, there has been a spider clinging (outside) to the living room window! How did it get there? Did it climb? Was it carried there by a passing tern? However it did, in the past several weeks, IT HAS GROWN BIGGER!--it is quite fat by now. So it is obviously getting enough to eat. Also, it is regularly, but not always, visible--does it hide out of sight just under the window frame? Does it wander over to see what is happening in 1711?

"Is Alt-emo a thing?" the puzzle made me wonder. I typed "alt-emo" into the search box of Youtube, and got a smattering of hits, none of which I felt inspired to follow (there was an "alt-emo makeup tutorial," in two parts, totaling over an hour. It had been reposted from Tik-tok.)

I have never heard the revealer. I can imagine someone saying it, just someone I would never want to meet. Like @EH and several other posters, I found this an unsatisfying puzzle. But I found I could spell backwards.

Best moment for me was seeing the first long backward word.  I have no idea why, but there is a tender place in my heart for backward words

Even post-solve, when my eyes fell on DOOR, my brain called out “Rood!”  I knew it was something but forgot what, then found that it’s an old term for a quarter of an acre.  That there is a term for a quarter of an acre just seemed so random to me that once again – and I don’t know how many times a day this happens – I fell in love with humanity.  

I liked the echoes of the climbing theme:
•	TBAR.
•	NOAH’S ARK, which rose as the downpour continued.
•	CABIN as part of an airplane.

I liked that moment when I looked at NOTATE and saw it as two words, as in, “That’s a very nice modern art museum, but it’s NO TATE!”

I liked seeing BIG TOP, because the constructor said in his notes to a previous puzzle that he worked as a circus juggler for ten years.

So, smiles on top of the fun of filling in.  Thank you for a lovely start to the day, Colin!

I felt clever when I solved it but somehow backwards words in a crossword don't feel that fun to me although I love just about every other Thursday trick! Still, I appreciate the hard work in construction and any puzzle with NARNIA in it makes me happy. Recently I have been re-listening to a podcast on C.S. Lewis's book "The Great Divorce" (which is not about divorce!), a book with so many layers and such depth that it's worth a read (or re-read). Lewis gets to the heart of the beauty and sheer difficulty of being human like no other writer. And (IMO) although he's a Christian apologist, his themes and insights are pretty universal and he writes with humor, compassion, and love. Maybe you'll enjoy it: ❤️https://open.spotify.com/show/5P4tYS815akoMPRNQ3TsU2

Almost a model Thursday puzzle. Solid theme with a nice "trick" and strong fill.

I was on the right "wavelength" today, and saw the trick with REBMILCKCOR. So I was done in fewer than 15 minutes, each of which I enjoyed.

Great job, Colin! A tight and tidy grid where some of the theme answers were guessable enough to reveal the theme themselves! I ended up with a BATIC/CARO which took a moment to track down, and initially had DISH for 30D which made the intersecting words a rather suss. Really enjoyed this puzzle!

I really like double and triple entendres, and this theme fit the bill! From answers that climb/scale to words you read up instead of down to a question every kickstart solicitation should answer. I’ve never watched an episode of shark tank but know the concept. An earlier comment sent me down this rabbit hole: KARO syrup is the best known corn syrup in my experience, which includes working in the grocery industry. People in the US may see more corn syrup because government subsidies to corn growers create a large surplus every year. As a brand name, KARO doesn’t seem to be used generically like heroin, flip phone, and escalator, which have all gone generic. Wikipedia has a dynamic list of genericized brand names - many of which were new to me! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_generic_and_genericized_trademarks I was surprised to learn Bayer still owns the trademark for aspirin, but lost it for heroin!

Here's a little, 1:30", praiseful Improvisation by Francis Poulenc, which hangs by a tenuous thread to today's theme, and which might be described as "alt-Czerny": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YHp1pkBmdHM

Although some found this fairly easy, I thought it was a decent Thursday workout, which I finished in around 10% under my average time. I also enjoyed the theme, as well as some of the clueing: “That little thing you do” for TIC. “Locale for a couples cruise” for NOAH’s ARK. “Tap it” for ALE. 

Also, I don’t know if it was an intentional part of the design, but I appreciated that WINDOW and WASHER were split by three black squares, suggesting someone working on more than one floor.

Great puzzle. For a Thursday, it was quite doable. The couples cruise was a given (but a fun clue). 17A was an old friend, and 61D made me smile. 43A gave this old-movie freak a lot of trouble, because in Toronto that channel is TCM. And it crossed with 35D, which... hmm... could only have one possible answer. Had never heard of the expression at 26D. But in the end, the light dawned and it all worked out splendidly. 

How nice to have a Thursday puzzle where fun outweighs frustration. Let's climb more mountains with  Colin Ernst.

When I saw the clue for 2D first thing, I thought we were being insulted...and then I got the REBM sequence (after I took out and restored IMMUNE) I thought we were being hosed...and then I calmed down and saw LIMBER before me!  The heavens opened, doves and angels floated down on a rainbow path while bluebirds sang, ...and so on and so forth.  

However, DHubby could not explain DOES IT SCALE ...and I don't want to call our financial advisor with a question from the NYT Xword puzzle, so Oh well.  Got the puzzle, didn't "get it" and can't be made to care.  Might have to read the Column.  Need more coffee.

Right after I put in CAR at 1-Across, I confidently entered ROCK CLIMBER at 3-Down.  However, I felt pretty sure that 39-Across, the "capital in Anatolia" was ANKARA, which didn't fit with the M of ROCK CLIMBER.

I knew something was amiss and, fortunately, figured it out pretty quickly from there.  It's Thursday, and things always look a little bit different on Thursdays.

I didn't reveal the revealer until I was almost done with the puzzle, and found it mildly disappointing at first, not being an inhabitant of the corporate boardroom.  But I've seen an episode or two of "Shark Tank", and now it makes perfect sense to me.

Nice Thursday; good change-up.  Thanks, Colin Ernst.

In my culinary experience, the only use of KARO corn syrup is to make pecan pie (for Thanksgiving).  In general, one buys a half-bottle than one needs, and that sticky bottle lives in one's kitchen cupboard for years thereafter.

You feel me?
Isn’t TMC an error that should be noted?  TCM.
60A - High End Suit, appearing in today’s puzzle the same day Giorgio ARMANI passed away. RIP good sir!
51:30, my first Thursday gold star!🌟 With a little help from the boyfriend, but who's counting....
Fun solve, witty theme , and trivia in my bailiwick - all in all a great Thursday . Things are looking UP :)
Unplanned, I'm sure, but let's appreciate the homage paid in 60A.

Tough one for me, had to take some breaks and ponder and it still a long time for the trick to finally dawn on me. And - yeah, cheated a little bit. No big deal. Truly remarkable puzzle find today. A Sunday from January 2, 1972 by the great Frances Hansen with the title: "Off and reeling." Five 23 letter grid-spanning entries in that one. The first clue being: 29a. "Limerick, with 58, 82, 109 and 138 Across" And then those referenced answers were all just clued as "See 29 across." And the answers in order from top to bottom: IHEARDOFASEAGOINGROVERW HOSAILEDFROMMANHATTANTO DOVERHELEFTNEWYEARSEVEW ITHAFLASKUPHISSLEEVEAND GOTTHEREALITTLEHUNGOVER Whew. Amazing piece of construction but can't imagine I would have had a chance with that one. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/2/1972&g=29&d=A ....

I’m surprised there isn’t more discussion of the spooky coincidental nature of 60A coming on the exact day that he passes away. I realize there are coincidences all the time between crossword puzzles and the “real world,” but that one struck me as quite… remarkable.

Yes - I heard about Armani while I was doing the puzzle. ****insert twilight zone music here****
But I don't want it to take away from Colin Ernst's lovely Thursday effort. 
Have a great day!

Re: 26D; here's a cautionary/explanatory tale. For many years, my family has been stopping at a mom-and-pop smokehouse in the Adirondacks. Their products are all excellent, and their bacon is the best I've ever had. I was delighted when they started doing mail order, and sending Christmas gift baskets to my family members became my tradition. And then Rachel Ray featured them on her show. (She's a local.) Well, the orders started pouring in, and the owners decided that they could not keep up with the increased demand without sacrificing quality, so they shut down the mail order operation. In short, the business did not scale. Hope that helps.
Alas, Giorgio Armani passed away today, so the clue was timely if not prescient.
Lovely, and 35D was the aha for me!

I figured out the trick almost immediately, and really thought I was on track for a Thursday PB! Filled GRAPEVINE, ROCKCLIMBER, WINDOW WASHER with minimal crosses, which really jump started the puzzle.

Then I hit two snags. The first was my repeat insistence that TCM was the only relevant cinephile channel (this is not the first time I’ve gotten stuck in this line of thinking). The second was trying to blind fill “Uncle Ben” for 25D, seeing that it didn’t fit, then bailing on the comic book angle entirely. Took me an embarrassing number of crosses to see the real answer, at which point I had blown past any possible record.

(For those keeping score, 15:44 is where I ultimately landed)

At 64, I’m still learning new trivia from these puzzles.  “Does it scale?” (26D)  was not a phrase I had ever heard before and only solved it by crosssings. Similarly, knowing nothing about chess, “mate in three” (58D) was difficult for me.  However, I really appreciated the clueing of the themes at 3D and 35D bc I knew the answers and since they both “fit” lengthwise, I guessed the trick before getting the theme after just a few crossings.  Thank you for the fun, Mr. Ernst!
I’ve got an argument going that only the nytimes crossword gods can answer - did you know about Armani before print and swap out to one that referenced him? Or is this a good coincidence?
This one is an all-time fave. Fun solve with a clever, well constructed theme and rewarding “aha” moment. Scrabbling success!
I got it but I didn’t like it

I found this quite tough.
I actually thought at first that REB MILCKCOR was the name of a famous athlete I had never heard of! I got all the theme clues from the crossers, but had never heard of the revealer. 

I was puzzled about a connection between window cleaners and ropes, then remembered TV programmes with planks and ropes going up tall buildings. 

I celebrated being able to use one of my two facts about baseball, remembering HEROES just in time, but forgot IHOP again. I tend to think of kangaroos, not places to eat. 

Somehow the backwards clues just didn't chime with me.

I know it wasn't planned, but I'm surprised to see Karo in the puzzle, after seeing INVERT as a kind of sugar in yesterday's Strands. My mother was a fabulous cook and baker, as well as a teacher of home ec and chemistry (tiny school in the 1930s). One of her specialties was a chocolate fudge that had a creamy fine-grained texture I've not encountered since. Her secret was 2T of light Karo syrup. She explained that Karo was an invert sugar that changed the way the sugar crystalized in the fudge. 

So Hi Mom!

I still remember my first Thursday gold star. I came here so proud and read that it was apparently a very easy Thursday, not representative.

So I'm here about 5 years later to say I got a gold star and PB with this one, at 11:54. I have stopped measuring myself against what's "easy" for others (I still don't know many US references) and so should you. Just wanted to say it really is a learnable skill, in case you're not there yet.

I just saw the news that Giorgio Armani has passed away at 91. Fitting tribute for him to be in today's puzzle. https://www.vogue.com/article/giorgio-armani-the-italian-designer-who-changed-the-shape-of-fashion-has-died?utm_source=firefox-newtab-en-us

I needed Deb's help with this one.    I couldn't figure out how to put ROCK CLIMBER and SPIDERMAN in.  I didn't want to rebus all those letters.  So I read her column down as far as her discussion of rock climber, then went back to finish the themed answers and puzzle.  I stumbled in the SW corner, so a blue star for me today.  Clever puzzle.  I liked it.
Fitting tribute to Giorgio Armani, who passed away today.

Deb said in the Tricky Clues section: 
"54D. We’re not supposed to be thinking about substitutes for [Subs], but sandwiches: The answer is HEROS."  She left off something I thought was also tricky about the answer, its less common plural form (which the internet informs me that when used, usually refers to the sandwich).

Finished relatively quickly for me but got that dreaded "So Close" and spent waay too long before realising (or should I say realiZing) the problem in the GOMEs/AGONIsE cross 😂 

Great puzzle, though!

This might be my favorite clue ever:
63A Locale for a couples cruise?
I didn't like the Book of Mormon book clue! It is too obscure.

I enjoyed the theme today.  One of those EUREKA moments where it finally clicks and then half the puzzle solves itself.  Ten minutes of "This has to be ROCK CLIMBER but it doesn't fit!"

The Noah's Ark clue was excellent.

Bottom left is the part that gave me the most trouble because I was looking for the 'Great power' quote to be a philosopher or politician rather than SPIDERMAN, and also kept thinking it wsa TUXEDO rather than ARMANI.  Once I figured out what the hell the Flying Wallendas were it fell into place.

This was fun! It took figuring out the revealer to get any of the theme answers, but once I did, they all fell at once.

Nice to see the first few commenters liked the puzzle. No time to read the rest today, but yes, it was interesting to see Armani in there and I briefly wondered about a stop-the-presses moment--even though I know they are not possible in the digital/hard copy puzzle world.
Especially gratifying "aha" moment!

3D should be 52U, etc.

As others have said, it's Santiago. Not Sao Tiago.
Armani is a brand, not a suit.
Window Washers don't Scale, they use a motorized elevator... or ladder
Uncle Ben Popularized "With great power..." NOT spiderman :/
Thought the theme was pretty easy to figure out and not that interesting for a Thursday. Struggling to understand the clues for ESP and BLUE, any help please?

Fun! 

It took me a second longer than maybe it should have, reluctant as I was to correct DIsh ("ANKAsA! The capital of TURdEY, where cinephiles watch SUNSET BooBLEVARD on hMC"). 🙄 

I was also a little slow to see the theme because of the palindromic placement of R..L..R in ROCKCLIMBER. Could've just been my confusion, but I opt to believe it was clever misdirection. 

Anyway, what a cool puzz--thank you, Colin Ernst & eds.!
The coincidence of having 60-Across in today's puzzle is rather eerie!
Fun Thursday puzzle with a twist, but a bit too easy for me. I expect more of a challenge on a Thursday and this came in well under my Thursday average. Still, as I said, a fun puzzle.

Seriously,  I do like to see the finished puzzle too, but I also like to have some chance of solving it.  There was a zero chance of thinking that words would be spelled down to up.  That's not the way we learned to read.

A rare Thursday done with no lookups and not even reading the Wordplay column first! This was definitely a fun one. I hate rebuses,no metter how clever. Upside words I can live with as long as they're spelled correctly. And only a few minutes over my average time. Yay me!

I always look forward to a Thursday and discovering what the trick might be. I thought this was very clever. I was "hanging on" the whole time! (Specifically to DIsh and ROpeCLIMBER. Who says "ROpeCLIMBER"? 😂)

Comment count seems low for a Thursday. Is that because there was no rebus, or because the emus are gorging themselves? They haven't yet spit out my comment from 5 hours ago.
Maybe the comments moderation system DOESn'T SCALE with all the new Games subscribers.

I do think it was clever to construct a puzzle around that buzz phrase.
cnbc was running in the background while I worked on the puzzle. There's endless talk about hyper-scalers.

This was a beautiful puzzle (and I don't just say that because I have spent the last week hiking in the Mosel and seeing where a "bunch of fruit" grows)! 

I figured out the trick before I did the revealer, and then it was relatively quick work. Still- longer than average solve for a Thursday. What a fun headscratcher!

I don't think this useless fact has been mentioned.

SCALE also has a meaning in software production.  It's used to mean, suppose this app or web site suddenly gets really popular.

Will it be able to handle a sudden increase in demand graciously, or will it crash?

Of course, that has no relevance here, and as a purveyor of useless trivia, I thought I should point that out.

This was too cute! 3D and 35D had obvious answers, I thought, but the crosses didn't make any sense. I got a handful of letters in 7D, more confusion. Then the implication of "knows the ropes" dawned on me. It would only work one way. EUREKA!
Took a couple of clues to catch on to the emeht 😁 but didn’t have to AGONIZE very long. Given the news on the passing of ARMANI 60A was 💔. Nice solve thank you 👏👏

One more late puzzle find. Again - never seen another one like this. A Sunday from April 5, 1970 by Joan DeRoss with the title: "Two-way middles." Some theme clue and answer examples; "Subdue; baton stroke" BEATDOWNBEAT "Impend; aftermath of sorts" OVERHANGOVER "Rob, and support" HOLDUPHOLD "Enter with a paycheck" COMEINCOME And some other theme answers: PINHEADPIN SETUPSET GOTINGOT Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/5/1970&g=63&d=D ....
A person can discover the trickery and thrill in the larger process of solving but then get completely stymied by the small but critical difference between TCM and TMC.
Delightful aha-moment-inducing Thursday! Best clue: Couple's cruise locale... brilliant

Look at me, Secretary Kennedy. My hand is up. I’m one of those old people who has been denied a COVID shot. One pharmacy hadn’t received the new vaccine as of September 3. A major chain said I needed a prescription, even though I’m 75. But even if I got a prescription, they still couldn’t vaccinate me because some committee had to meet. So you’re wrong. Eligible people are being denied COVID vaccines.  And we won’t forget.

As Kublai Kahn’s sous-chef I can say with some authority that one either MINCES or CHOPS, but not both.  They are two distinct preparations.  DICING on the other hand is best left to the saucier. 

Also, being INTO something is not nearly as intense as being OBSESSED with something. I know this firsthand as I used to be only INTO doing unsolicited Ethel Merman impressions for complete strangers on late night subway rides while wearing my Kublai Kahn mask, but now I’m OBSESSED with it.

Working the puzzle online seems generally more problematic than working it in the newspaper.  There are the banners I've clicked on inadvertently and have to back out of, there are the crosses I need to check before entering an answer and have to keep scrolling the lists of clues up and down, there is the quirkiness of the software deciding that I mean to change direction when I don't and having to figure out where the letters wound up that should have been going in one direction and instead flew all over the puzzle, dropping in letters where I never meant them to go, and then I have to remember to find and take them out because they are not part of that fill and are taxing my brain like so many red herrings.  

My lord, it's a wonder I ever finish one of the darn things, and I only keep on truckin' because I do love them.

The Movie Channel shows whatever schlock Showtime doesn't want.

Cursed (2005) - Siblings (Christina Ricci, Jesse Eisenberg) search for the werewolf that attacked them.
Venom (2005) - A killer stalks teens (Agnes Bruckner, Jonathan Jackson, Laura Ramsey) in the swamps of Louisiana.
The Collector (2009) - A desperate thief finds that the house he planned to break into is rigged with deadly traps.

@Steve

As in chess puzzles. Often they show a board setup and challenge with "[check]mate in three".

@Mr Dave

Thanks. Not a chess guy.

@Steve

Chess players, good ones, can sometimes tell that no matter what their opponent does, they will be checkmated in the next three moves.  

This can come about when the board situation is such that the losing player has no choice but to make a bad move--because that's the only possible one.

In this case, the winning player might "announce" a checkmate, like "mate in three".

It's a big of a gamble, because if you're wrong, you look like an idiot.

@Steve
That was one of the last squares to fall for me. I ran the alphabet mentally, and when I got to "M" I knew that the phrase sounded vaguely familiar from the world of Chess.

@Francis

I wonder if it's bad chess etiquette to announce "mate in three". That would really upset me if I were playing.

@Mr Dave

I don't think it is.  I think it's a signal that there is no point in continuing the game.  A lot of the losing players often see the inevitable mate in advance, and have resigned.  

Also, resignations are very common way before the inevitable mate situations arises.

What *is* funny, though, is to announce a mate incorrectly.  One of the humorous rules I've seen for chess is "If you think you can 'announce' a mate, but are not sure, go ahead and do it.  Maybe your opponent will just resign."

@Jacqui J
The Big Top is another example of metonymy (which is clearly going to be my Word of the Week),  where a part of something is used to represent the whole. The Big Top used to refer to the largest of several tents that composed one circus. Its meaning has long since lapsed into the general meaning of circus.

All these cultural differences are so strange and so amazing! Of course we have circuses here, even if they are much less popular now than they used to be when I was a kid in the 1980s - back then the circus arriving in town was a major event, and everybody went to see the show. We're not talking some minor town, either, but Warsaw, the capital.

However, all the circuses I've seen over here only ever had the one, huge tent, so we never had a term equivalent to the Big Top.

In the 80s circuses still traveled as a caravan of small, old trucks pulling decades-old wooden trailers, sort of like the ones traditionally associated with Travelers. These days the few circuses that remain use much less romantic, huge semis.

Corn syrup is not a thing here. I also can't imagine any generic product, like sugar or whatever, having an actual *iconic* brand. The products of all the manufacturers are exactly the same, so brand matters not at all. We have different brands of sugar, of course, but all people ever look at when buying sugar is the price per kilo.

@Times Rita

FB does everything it can to track you and make money off you, using different technologies, also through third parties: via your browser and other apps you may be using. If you don't install software that prevents tracking, and if you don't deny third party cookies (and similar technologies), FB will track you everywhere.

I'm not on any social media, for many reasons, but years of researching telecoms and over-the-top services were one of the main factors. When you know FB's (and other behemoths') business practices and the technology behind them, you'd have to be crazy not to abhor the whole thing and avoid it like the plague.

I can't recall any circus sideshows, as such. As I recall it, sometimes a fair would be organized around a circus, possibly even by the same people, but that involved things like small amusement rides or shooting galleries, not bearded ladies or the like.

So were [Wild couples cruise?] (Adam Vincent, 4/16/24) and [Couples cruise vessel?] (Elizabeth Gorski, 1/19/08). There might have been others that clued some variant of NOAH’S ARK.

I’m fine with the NYT recycling good clues now and then. There will always be someone who hasn’t seen that clue before, in the same way that when an orchestra performs something like Beethoven’s 5th, there’s always someone in the audience who has never heard it live.

But I do like to see credit where it’s due, whether that’s the wonderfully talented Liz Gorski or Will Shortz and his team.

@Mr Dave

Funny.

 I always took it to mean that business processes could grow to accommodate increase demand.

Re Francis's comment, I thought scalable software meant it could handle higher volumes than expected upon roll out, probably by adding servers or something like that.

@Renegator

Databases are tricky.  You want them to perform exceptionally well, so you might make several copies so that, like servers, there is always one ready to take a request.

The problem is keeping all these "instances" of the database synched up.  One design is that the databases always try to exchange information with each other to have the same data.

But that takes time, and it's possible, even probably, that a request may get stale information from a DB before it can be updated.

As a consequence, the Casandra database (which I have experience with, is called "eventually consistent".  While that sounds bad eventually will almost certainly be a second or two.
